node.contents: Have you tried to print out the size of the object in a test program?

node.contents: I believe that it is up to the JVM how much memory it needs for each instance of an object. You are still thinking too C-ish. Just trust the JVM.

astNode.text: I believe that it is up to the JVM how much memory it needs for each instance of an object. You are still thinking too C-ish. Just trust the JVM.

node.contents: @OdayMansour, how can I do sizeof in Java. That operator is in C only.

node.contents: You could look at [my question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12501328/java-memory-usage) - there are some nice answers on how java manages to allocate memory.

astNode.text: You could look at [my question](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12501328/java-memory-usage) - there are some nice answers on how java manages to allocate memory.

node.contents: @Philipp, so will JVM can use any size? I will have huge HashMap, and I have fear of Hear Shortage.

astNode.text: @Philipp, so will JVM can use any size? I will have huge HashMap, and I have fear of Hear Shortage.

node.contents: It may depend on the VM. My experience was 12bytes + fields (int = 4 byte). You can try to measure it by create e.g. 10000 and ask the VM before and after how much memory is used.

astNode.text: It may depend on the VM. My experience was 12bytes + fields (int = 4 byte). You can try to measure it by create e.g. 10000 and ask the VM before and after how much memory is used.

node.contents: Theoretically, the JVM could use some internal optimizations (like using copy-on-write or out-optimizing unnecessary variables) so that the size of some objects is even less than the sum of their members.

astNode.text: Theoretically, the JVM could use some internal optimizations (like using copy-on-write or out-optimizing unnecessary variables) so that the size of some objects is even less than the sum of their members.

node.contents: When I loaded map with around 70000 keys, and when I serialized it to file, file was of around 18 MB, so will my map be of 18 MB in heap?

astNode.text: When I loaded map with around 70000 keys, and when I serialized it to file, file was of around 18 MB, so will my map be of 18 MB in heap?

node.contents: No. It can never be of the same size as that in C because an object is created on heap whereas a reference variable is created on Stack. So therefore, it won't be of the same size.

astNode.text: No. It can never be of the same size as that in C because an object is created on heap whereas a reference variable is created on Stack. So therefore, it won't be of the same size.

node.contents: @user1508907 I think it's more than in the file. Open HashMap source. K+V is stored in Entry, K(Long) 16 bytes; T - 24; Entry - 24; total - 64 bytes per entry (K,V)

astNode.text: @user1508907 I think it's more than in the file. Open HashMap source. K+V is stored in Entry, K(Long) 16 bytes; T - 24; Entry - 24; total - 64 bytes per entry (K,V)

node.contents: It may depend on JVM, but in practice, for 32-bit JVM, an object = 8-byte header + fields. Header consist of Id + reference to class.

astNode.text: It may depend on JVM, but in practice, for 32-bit JVM, an object = 8-byte header + fields. Header consist of Id + reference to class.

node.contents: Fields size depends on field type, reference - 8 bytes, boolean - 1 byte, etc

astNode.text: Fields size depends on field type, reference - 8 bytes, boolean - 1 byte, etc

node.contents: Besides objects are aligned to 8 bytes. That is your A takes 16 bytes. Minimum size = 8 bytes, no fields.

astNode.text: Besides objects are aligned to 8 bytes. That is your A takes 16 bytes. Minimum size = 8 bytes, no fields.

node.contents: More here http://www.javamex.com/tutorials/memory/object_memory_usage.shtml

astNode.text: More here http://www.javamex.com/tutorials/memory/object_memory_usage.shtml

node.contents: If you use Oracle JVM you can use sun.misc.Unsafe to investigate object structure, byte by byte.

astNode.text: If you use Oracle JVM you can use sun.misc.Unsafe to investigate object structure, byte by byte.
